unnormalised: So, someone asked about how important marks are in India, especially after 10th and 12th. It's a question every student here grapples with, right?
normalised: So, someone asked about how important marks are in India, especially after tenth and twelfth. It's a question every student here grapples with, right?

unnormalised: Well, honestly, it's complicated. Your 10th grade % and 12th grade % are HUGE in the Indian context, especially for the initial part of your career. Think of it this way: they're the first filters. Want to get into a decent college for undergrad? Your class 12 score is gonna be under the scanner. For engineering, a good score in PCM (Physics, Chemistry, Maths) is super important, ideally 90%+. For arts and commerce, similar high percentages are expected in top colleges like Hindu College in Delhi or St. Xavier’s in Mumbai.
normalised: Well, honestly, it's complicated. Your tenth grade percent and twelfth grade percent are huge in the Indian context, especially for the initial part of your career. Think of it this way: they're the first filters. Want to get into a decent college for undergrad? Your class twelve score is going to be under the scanner. For engineering, a good score in P-C-M (Physics, Chemistry, Maths) is super important, ideally ninety percent plus. For arts and commerce, similar high percentages are expected in top colleges like Hindu College in Delhi or St. Xavier’s in Mumbai.

unnormalised: See, for many undergraduate courses, especially at top institutions, cut-offs are often based on the percentage. Getting 98% in your CBSE exams doesn't guarantee a spot, but it sure gives you a fighting chance. Even private colleges often have minimum eligibility criteria, often around 60% in 12th. So, initially, those numbers define the options you have.

unnormalised: Then, when you are looking for a job, particularly your first job after graduation, many companies look at your academic record. They might have a cut-off like 60% throughout - 10th, 12th, and graduation. If you don't meet that criterion, you might not even get shortlisted for an interview. This is super common, especially for mass recruiters.

unnormalised: Now, does this mean your life is ruined if you scored, say, 70% in class 12? Absolutely not! There are many other avenues. Private colleges often have lower cutoffs. Skills are also extremely important. If you develop a strong portfolio, particularly in tech, where practical skills matter a lot, companies often overlook academic scores. Think coding boot camps, freelance projects, and contributing to open source.

unnormalised: After a few years of experience, things change. No one cares about your 10th grade % when you have 5+ years of experience in a particular field. What matters then is your skills, your performance, and your track record. But those initial hurdles, those first few filters, they definitely weigh your 10th and 12th grade % heavily.

What matters then is your skills, your performance, and your track record. But those initial hurdles, those first few filters, they definitely weigh your tenth and twelfth grade percent heavily.

unnormalised: So, to summarize: Yes, marks matter a lot, especially in the initial phase of your career in India. But they're not the be-all and end-all. Develop skills, explore different paths, and prove your worth beyond those numbers. And remember, someone who scored 99% in their ICSE board isn't necessarily smarter or more successful than someone who scored 75%. It's just a different path. Good luck, bhai!
